159819: Mesa Pegasus.author: Aquillion
159819: Mesa Pegasus.text_parsed:
@BonniePrinceCharlie: You're underestimating the advantage of directing all the damage to a 1/1 banding creature.

Consider this: If I band a Mesa Pegasus with a Serra Angel and attack with it, and you block with a Shivan Dragon (or vice-versa, if you attack and I block), no matter how much damage you pump into the dragon, I can dump it all onto the pegasus. That's the real advantage of banding: It lets you decide which of your creatures die, while putting them into bands big enough to force anyone who blocks or is blocked by them into an unfavorable trade-off (because anything that blocks or is blocked by the band is probably going to die itself.)
159819: Mesa Pegasus.text_posted:

159820: Vesuvan Doppelganger.author: Aquillion
159820: Vesuvan Doppelganger.text_parsed:
While this was an incredibly fun card, Control Magic was almost always better.

If your opponent has the strongest creature in play, stealing it is going to do more for you than copying it.

If you control the strongest creature in play, you're probably already winning and can afford to save your Control Magic as backup in case something goes wrong.

Additionally, creature removal is far more common than enchantment removal. This card is a prime target for creature removal, whereas if someone wastes a removal card on something you swiped with Control Magic, it's a +1 for you. Even if you completely waste something you stole with Control Magic on chump blocking, it's still a one-for-one.
159820: Vesuvan Doppelganger.text_posted:

This card is a prime target for creature removal, whereas if someone wastes a removal card on something you swiped with Control Magic, it's a +1 for you.  Even if you completely waste something you stole with Control Magic on chump blocking, it's still a one-for-one.

159821: Mindstab Thrull.author: blurrymadness
159821: Mindstab Thrull.text_parsed:
Works well with Funeral Charm:
-Grants fear to allow you to get in for the discard three
-If you've put them into topdeck mode, Funeral charm is the only mono-black instant-speed discard available, lock them out of their ability to play it!
-It's discard anyway, so if you got the discard three off you can use it to ensure they'll discard another card. Minus 4 cards should put nearly any hand into top-deck mode.

This guy is great as he's one of the non-targeted discards available for black. The fact that Funeral Charm + him can be maindecked and can only be hated on with creature kill or with Stifle makes him very powerful. He can't be hated out with Leyline of sanctity, and you don't need targeted discard when the number is as high as this.

Used next to Unearth and Dark Ritual you nigh guarantee to nab your opponents hand early in the game, and if you're black and you and your opponent are both topdecking, you're in great shape!

Also notice that he's a finisher in a pinch. If you screwed them out of their creatures and hand with a good control deck, you can beat them for 2 while you wait for them to find an answer.

159822: River Merfolk.author: MattLynn
159822: River Merfolk.text_parsed:
@NoobOfLore: Rivers flow with gravity and sculpt valleys after falling down waterfalls and gathering tributaries into a delta. Downhill suggests there is up"hill" aka mountain. So yeah, RIVER merfolk get MOUNTAINwalk.

Think about the Colorado River and the Grand Canyon or Hoover Dam...gravity, mountains and elevation are all intertwined.

Not that blue needs more evasion (heck, it usually has the best kind there is: unblockable) but trivially, this is the ONLY blue mountainwalker and has an awesome tribe to work with.

159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.author: sendai45
159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.text_parsed:
Unsurprisingly, I am confused. The second sentence instructs you to draw a card. Will this additional draw cause Chains of Mephistopheles to trigger anew? If so, the process will repeat until your hand is empty. This entire card could be rewritten as:

"If a player would draw a card except the first one he or she draws in his or her draw step each turn, that player discards his or her hand and he or she places the top card of his or her library into his or her graveyard."

Further, specifying WHICH draw in a turn is exempt is less important than the fact you only get ONE card per turn.

"If a player would draw a card beyond his or her first each turn, he or she discards his or her hand and he or she places the top card of his or her library into their graveyard."

Remove the replacement effect and the card draw occurs. This eliminates the need for a mill effect, as the card would go to hand and then graveyard naturally.

"If a player draws a card beyond his or her first each turn, he or she discards his or her hand."

And finally, do away with all the "his or her" nonsense:

"If a player draws a card beyond their first each turn, they discard their hand."

Clean, simple, and still a draw hoser. And look! There is room for flavor text!

159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.author: altheuser
159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.text_parsed:
If you want to know what this does and does not do:

It DOES prevent any sort of card advantage by ensuring that hand sizes increase only by drawing one card during each players draw step.

It DOES NOT force you to discard your hand and mill one.

If you think that Chains triggers itself you are wrong. The replacement effect happens once. I mean, do you think really believe that a Cunning Sparkmage causes infinite damage when you have a Furnace of Rath out? The effect on Chains is wordy, but it is treated just the same. You replace the card draw ONCE.

It's almost like each draw is replaced with a {0} cycling ability on any card in the players hand. If they have no cards in hand, a draw is replaced by a mill.

159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.author: Luke_BPC
159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.text_parsed: The original text is clearer, strange as it might seem. The Oracle text tries to word it in the same standard as new cards, but by using the word draw a few too many times it ends up being more ambiguous than helpful. The rullings help. Replacement effects happen only once, but more than one may happen in succession. If you have two of these out, any card drawn beyond the first will cause a player to discard a card. If he does, then he'll have to discard another card, drawing one if he does, or milling one if he doesn't. If you keep tabs on your opponent's hand and own the board, you can cast a Howling Mine or similar to eat through your opponent's deck, or force him to draw and discard more. It gets pretty evil with a board with Bloodchief's Ascension, Lilliana's Caress and the Mine. Each draw step, your opponent will get a card. Then he'll discard a card, the Caress will hit for two, the Ascension will either get a counter or hit for two drain.

If he does, then he'll have to discard another card, drawing one if he does, or milling one if he doesn't. 159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.author: stmcallister
159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.text_parsed:
"If a player would draw a card, discard a card. If that player discarded a card, they draw a card"

Because the player would draw a card for discarding, this is again substituted with another discard.
So, a player who draws extra cards would discard their whole hand and then mill one card.

Usually Oracle better clarifies those old fine-print rules text cards like this. In this case it's utterly confusing. If I was a Magic newbie and came across that I'd have no idea in hell what this card does.

Both can provide offense for a discard deck. I never thought of this as a mill card, then again, "mill decks" as we know them now hardly existed in Chains' day.

159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.author: Salient
159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.text_parsed:
Check out the awesome errata text: "Here's what happens when Chains of Mephistopheles replaces a player's draw" is as close as Wizards will ever come to admitting "our Oracle text is awful and we're sorry." :)

For those who are curious about the "one card infinite loop" -- nope. For the same reason that Mox Diamond actually will come into play after you discard one land, Chains of Mephistopheles actually will let you draw a card after you've discarded exactly one card. Replacement effects like this are static abilities, not triggered abilities -- they describe a change to how the game is played, rather than an ability which triggers or resolves. (This also means you can't respond to the replacement effect with an activated ability or an instant or even a mana ability. It's a bit weird. I was asking about this on Wizards' Q&A a while ago; I'll edit this comment to link to that Q&A thread sometime later.)

In the case of Mox Diamond, the change-in-gameplay only matters once, at the time when Mox Diamond first attempts to enter play. In the case of Chains of Satan, the change-in-gameplay matters whenever a player is drawing an extra card.

Hope this helps...

159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.author: GrimjawxRULES
159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.text_parsed:
The oracle seems like it could need a bit of rewriting to make it easier to understand:

"If you would draw a card other than the first card you draw during your draw step, you discard a card first before drawing. If you can't, you skip the draw and put the top card of your library into your graveyard."

There, that's better. It's still the correct mechanic, I just attempted to clarify it.

Basically, this completely hoses spells and abilities that causes players to draw cards by causing them to discard a card before each time they get to draw. In case they have no cards in hand to discard, they get milled 1 card instead and don't get to draw. As it is, it hoses blue pretty efficiently with the exception of cards such as Fact or Fiction which doesn't use the draw mechanic, but just puts the cards into your hand.

Unique, cheap, hoses draw spells and combos pretty well with Forced Fruition and force-draw decks (Howling Mine for example).
4.5/5

159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.author: Werewolf-
159823: Chains of Mephistopheles.text_parsed:
The key thing to remember about this card is that it doesn't apply to the first card each player draws during his draw step. It ONLY applies to drawing extra cards each turn, and it only really hurts when the player has an empty hand, because otherwise he'll just discard the useless crap and keep the stuff he needs. And it has to be cards "drawn," too--the wording on Fact or Fiction and Necropotence, for example, says "put into your hand," which evades this enchantment's effects. Lastly, it applies to you, too, not just your opponent.

All in all, it's unique and flavorful (as most cards from Legends block are), but it's only useful in pretty strict situations.

159824: Elder Land Wurm.author: doolydooly

159824: Elder Land Wurm.text_posted: Mr_Hendry: He is a creature with Defender until he blocks once, then he loses Defender. The use of the Defender keyword prevents him from attacking until he has blocked at least once.

159826: Serpent Generator.author: NARFNra
159826: Serpent Generator.text_parsed:
@Jeryc_Onyx

Notice that the tokens don't specify combat damage.

So if you're trying to make a deck based entirely around this card strategy(i.e. poison counters no infect), you'll want;

Craptons of colorless mana; Cloudpost, Urzatron, Candelabra of Tawnos, Artifact mana cards (like Vedalken), etc
Ways to decrease the cost: Power Artifact, possibly some sort of artifact -> creature + heartstone/training grounds combo
Ways to increase token number: Doubling Season/Parallel Lives/populate cards (fairly obvious but), anything that untaps artifacts (Voltaic/Galvanic Key), etc.
Proliferate: Contagion stuff.

But most importantly, to make best use of the fact they aren't limited to combat damage, damage source tricks;

Pandemonium: Ability essentially becomes "{T}: Target player gets a poison counter, put a 1/1 Snake artifact creature token into play." It also makes you not feel bad about chump blocking. Shut up Debilitator Web. Portcullis might combo with this?

There's probably more somewhere but I can't think of any good ones. Suggestions anyway?

159830: Energy Arc.author: Mode
159830: Energy Arc.text_parsed:
A one-sided Fog/Holy Day with an improved version of Vitalize (unless some of the creatures have shroud).
And unblocked attackers can be untapped as well to prevent any combat damage. Not too shabby.

The easiest use of this would be attacking with all creatures and surprise your opponent when he attacks,
but i think this card has more potential.

This might work quite well with Sky Hussar to buy some time (without card disadvantage) - even better should your creatures have -abilities like and/or profit from blocking like Perimeter Captain - especially those that would normally just survive a single combat (or not as easily), like Goldenglow Moth, or Kaijin of the Vanishing Touch, Vertigo Spawn and Psychic Membrane.
Wooly Razorback also ain't bad since its damage would be prevented anyways (regarding the use for card advantage with Sky Hussar now), and it synergizes with another creatures that goes well with the Hussar, Leech Bonder.

The possibility of mass targeting can also be easily abused with Horobi, Death's Wail or (to stay in the colors) Cowardice. Livewire Lash should also work nicely. Cephalid Illusionist interestingly also triggers from that, and a -ability that does the same as Energy Arc's damage prevention for a single creature.

159832: Lim-Dûl's Vault.author: DimirSnail
159832: Lim-Dûl's Vault.text_parsed:
5/5, any day of the year.

Maybe one of the best cards I have ever encountered for Legacy play. At the very least, it's a Cruel Tutor & Index with flash. This is a universally legal "any card" tutor for 2 mana. Demonic Tutor, Demonic Consultation: illegal in Legacy, and for good reason.

Already 5/5. The following is just a potential bonus.

In clarification of a prior controversy, Corey_bayoudragonfly is mistaken; tcollins is correct:
This can get you any 5 cards, not just 5 cards consecutive at the time of resolution.

Keep in mind, with a library count indivisible by 5, you are not stuck with distinct, immiscible groups of 5. Every complete loop through your library allows you to migrate your desired 5 cards a little closer to each other. Once they are consecutive, it's just a matter of time before they surface as a group.

Granted, this is just hypothetical. Even if you're perfectly efficient, with around 50 cards in your library (but not a number divisible by 5), it could still take around 10 passes through the whole thing to both gather your 5 cards and wait for them to surface together. So we're potentially talking upwards of 100 repetitions of the process described on the card, and thus upwards of 100 life as well. Doing the math, it comes out to exactly... 1 very annoyed opponent (more in multiplayer).

However, in the event that you have a ridiculous excess of life, you and your opponent could always just agree to take this card to read something like ", Pay 100 life: If the number of cards in your library is not divisible by 5, then search your library for any 5 cards and exile them. Shuffle your library and put the exiled cards on top of it in any order." Now read that effect out of context and tell me honestly that the border of the card it came from isn't silver.

But if I were your opponent, I'd be inclined to make you play it out as punishment for not just using a Doomsday.

159832: Lim-Dûl's Vault.author: Pinto331
159832: Lim-Dûl's Vault.text_parsed:
It's impossible to deny that this card is powerful but it's also the kind of card I don't like, especially in EDH where I'm seeing it crop up a fair bit.

It just slows down the game having everyone wait while you sort through that many cards, deciding if you should throw them on the bottom or how you want to sort them. It's a solitaire kind of card, and that's not what, at least amongst my friends, EDH is about. I would always prefer a Fact or Fiction effect over this in that format, if only for the interaction.

159833: Tornado.author: majinara
159833: Tornado.text_parsed:
I love that card. Have it in each commander/edh deck of mine that can support it.

3 mana: destroy target permanent? Hell yeah. You can even play it once in your own and once in each other players turn. Lands, planeswalkers, everything.

What's also nice: if you target something and your opponent sacrifices the target, gives it shroud or does anything in response, and the tornados ability is countered, then it also gets no velocity counter, which means you don't have to pay more life next time you use it again.

The life loss is also not much of a problem. If you activate it 3 times you lost 9 life, but you got rid of 3 permanents which would have probably caused you to lose more.

It's also a great card in matters of multiplayer politics. While this card is in play, many players won't attack or annoy you, knowing that you can destroy permanents for just 3 mana at instant speed.

4/5

159843: Icatian Town.author: Lateralis0ne
159843: Icatian Town.text_parsed:
I couldn't disagree with you more, beowulf. The flavor alone is incredible, from the effect to the cost to the art to the flavor text to the relevancy this card has within its own set and block. The cost is a little high, but you're comparing it to cards now; that's a huge fallacy, considering where the game is now and where it was when this was new. The citizen deal makes sense to me, as well, and I can see an argument for why it wasn't changed in the grand creature type. I think that adding "Human Citizen" might have been an okay idea, but then again, it would ruin the flavor of this card, which is very potent and (for me) worth keeping the integrity of the original printing.

Yes, I'm a major Vorthos, but that's what appeals to me about Magic in the first place. As such, cards like this just set my brain whirling with stories, lore, myths and customs that these Icatians might have had in their day.

159843: Icatian Town.author: Aquillion
159843: Icatian Town.text_parsed:
This card was overcosted and mostly not that useful even when it first came out (it could occasionally be valuable in white weenie decks with Crusade and Jihad, but decks like those weren't supposed to get to six mana anyway; usually you'd rather Armageddon first.)

However, the idea behind it was very sharp, even if they missed the balance point this time. Fallen Empires was the first set to really play around heavily with tokens, and they were a bit overly-cautious about them as a result. (Especially since earlier token-generators like The Hive and Serpent Generator had been flatly overcosted; they were probably trying to avoid balancing too far away from those.)
159843: Icatian Town.text_posted:

However, the idea behind it was very sharp, even if they missed the balance point this time.  Fallen Empires was the first set to really play around heavily with tokens, and they were a bit overly-cautious about them as a result. 159845: Seasinger.author: blindthrall
159845: Seasinger.text_parsed: Situational? You do not have this in the right deck. Expensive? It's a Control Magic that can be retargeted. For three mana. Compared to Dominating Licid, looks pretty cheap to me. Fragile? Learn to use counterspells. It may as well cost 1{U}{U}{U}{U} and have shroud. And if you're out of counters, it's always drawing removal away from your islandwalkers. In a certain deck, this is the biggest threat. And that deck has Rite of Replication. Yes, six of these things is a terrible thing to behold. And if you doubt I've ever pulled that off, High Tide.

159845: Seasinger.author: aznxknightz
159845: Seasinger.text_parsed:
I don't see what's so bad about this card. It's an uncommon that can take control of a card and only requires 3 mana to cast (plus 1 turn unless has haste). Play something like Aqueduct's Will or Spreading Seas and have a sacrifice outlet out as well.

Here, i'll even do a play by play:
T1: Island.
T2: Island, Spreading Seas to screw with their land.
T3: Swamp, Seasinger.
T4: Bloodthrone Vampire/Vampire Aristocrat. Use Seasinger, and sacrifice controlled creature to Vampire before end of opponent's turn. Congratulations, you've locked down your opponent unless they have removal spells.

159845: Seasinger.author: blurrymadness
159845: Seasinger.text_parsed:
What the heck?! No one mentioned you can untap her at instant speed and redo her ability as many times as you like on the stack before it "counts".

I.E. if you have untappers, in response to her tapping you untap her, and retap her, and untap her. Her abilities resolve and she's still tapped so steals as many creatures as times you untapped.

Call that a bad card I call you a big newb :s.

Pemmin's Aura and this = Game.

159846: Icatian Lieutenant.author: holgir
159846: Icatian Lieutenant.text_parsed:
Hm, I agree with you most of the time Mode, but in this case I think the card is not as bad as your irony (and his rating at time of this writing) tries to indicate. I admit that he is far from being an allstar and you expect at least a 2/2 for , especially in modern times taking such powerhouses as Veteran Armorer or Veteran Swordsmith for granted. But this little guy can decide a late game when you can pump the one unblocked soldier for the last few points of damage.
That said he is probably not making the cut today with the huge m.a.ss of possible soldiers for a casual tribal deck that lets even better candidates fall by the wayside with ease.

159846: Icatian Lieutenant.author: Aquillion
159846: Icatian Lieutenant.text_parsed:
I believe this was the first Soldier support ever printed.

At the time, tribes with support almost always paid for it by being generally weak individually (eg. goblins, merfolk); the reason he's weak is because he was supporting a tribe that was decent already. Obviously things have changed a lot since then. Technically he's better than he was because the Great Creature Update gave many more things the Soldier type, but we also got far-better support for it since then.
